Function.Name: MOD E2E - Core Service Management MQB (F42-ID: 4270045)
MOD E2E - Core Service Communication MQB (F42-ID: 4270045)
MOD E2E - Core Service Authentication MQB (F42-ID: 4270045)

TestCaseEntry.Text: The core service master shall handle a so-called CSM user profile consisting of: - personalized service list - personalized vehicle local service state - personalized privacy group settings
E2: LSD request is sent to backend for the current user, privacy mode Tracking is selected
The information reflects the actual local vehicle service states, privacy group settings for "tracking" are shown
A2: change privacy mode to tracking
A3: go to MBB admin tool-> vehcile monitoring->user profiles and select a user profile
A4: select "show operation list", use latest version of operation list and select "vehicle"
A5: check if operation list contains:
At a first start up the vehicle has to do a initinal startup
E1: OCU and MIB are booting. OCU does not start R&P
CoreServiceMaster(OCU) sends relevant servicelist to CoreServiceClients(MIB) by using RSI notifyServiceListChanged message OR BAP ServiceList Changed-Array 00 00 FF
As long as no response from the MBB arrived, the CoreServiceMaster shall use the persistently stored service list.
E1: no more communication to backend possible
E4: vehicle uses the stored servicelist,

MIB HMI indicates the using of a persistent servicelist by using the BAP SynchronisationState.Bit[1] OR OCU RSI indicates usage of persistent SL via VIWI by setting serviceListSynchronization to false
The system shall load all data of the currently active CSM user profile, so that all feature for core services management can be used
E1: user is logged in, last user-specific privacy settings and user-specific settings for activated/deactivated services are used
A1: log in personal IAA user
The OCU / cGW shall map the information coming from the ServiceList (GLCS) to the fields in BAP_ENI ServiceList (0x16)
E2: OCU maps the information coming from the servicelist to BAP-ENI
The CSSW shall map the information coming from the fields in BAP_ENI ServiceList (0x16) to the fields in RSI serviceManagement.services
E2: OCU maps the information coming from the servicelist to RSI

The OCU shall indicate whether an online service list has been received from backend. This shall be indicated within BAP_ENI ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit[1] as defined in the BAP_ENI Specification.
E1: no more communication to backend possible
E2: ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit[1] indicates offline service list (not synchronized)
E3: vehicle uses the stored servicelist,
BAP_ENI ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit[1] indicates offline service list (not synchronized)
CoreServiceMaster notifies HMI about an updated servicelist
A2: turn clamp15 and clampS off
A3: turn clamp15 and clampS on
A4: turn clamp15 and clampS off
A6: turn clamp15 and clampS on

The OCU shall indicate whether an online service list has been received from backend. This shall be indicated within BAP_ENI ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit[1] as defined in the BAP_ENI Specification.
E2: ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit is set to "not synchronized"
A1: do a reboot via ODIS Hex Service 1102 without changing clamps
A2: check ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit before OCU receives new SL
A3: check ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit again after OCU receives new SL

The OCU shall indicate whether an online service list has been received from backend. This shall be indicated within BAP_ENI ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit[1] as defined in the BAP_ENI Specification.
E2: ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit is set to "not synchronized"
A2: check ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit before OCU has successfully received SL
A3: wait for SL on BAP

The OCU shall indicate whether an online service list has been received from backend. This shall be indicated within BAP_ENI ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit[1] as defined in the BAP_ENI Specification.
E3: check ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit is set to "not synchronized"
E5: check ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit is set to "synchronized"
A2: turn clamp15 and clampS off
A4: turn clamp15 and clampS on

The OCU shall indicate whether an online service list has been received from backend. This shall be indicated within BAP_ENI ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit[1] as defined in the BAP_ENI Specification.
E3: ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit is set to "not synchronized"
E4: ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit is set to "not synchronized"
A2: turn clam30 off and on again
A3: check ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit again before OCU has done successfully R&P
A4: check ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit again before OCU receives new SL but after R&P is done
A5: check ConnectionState.SynchronizationState.Bit again after OCU receives new SL
After the initial startup, the OCU shall request the communication parameter from backend
all parameters are received in a full and single set of the GetCommunicationParametersResponse with HTTP Response Code 200
A1: Turn clamp30 and clamp15 on
A2: Wait for R&P is finished and check OCU traces

All CoreServiceClients shall provide their capabilities to the CoreServiceMaster. The CoreServiceMaster shall communicate the vehicle capabilities to the backend. After each startup the CoreServiceMaster sends a hash of the vehicle capabilities to the backend to the MBB. If nessecary, the MBB requests the entire Installed Base from CoreServiceMaster.
E1: OCU and MIB are booting up
E3: - InstalledBaseGetRequest gets HTTP status code 404
- InstalledBasePutRequest Request Payload contains operation entries and job entries of all existing ECUs
- InstalledBasePutRequest gets HTTP status code 200, response paylaod contains service list collection with services of all existing ECUs
A3: after R&P: check OCU logs
The transceivermodul shall report its capabilities to the CoreServiceMaster after clamp30
E3: transceivermodul reports its capabilities to the OCU
A1: delete transceivermodul's capabilities on OCU
A2: turn clamp15 and clamp30 off
A3: turn clamp30 and clamp on again
The transceivermodul shall report its capabilities to the CoreServiceMaster after ODIS reset
After boot up TM reports its capabilites to OCU
A1: delete transceivermodul's capabilities on OCU
A2: go into ODIS and do hex reset 0x1102
The core service master shall send a service list request to the backend, if a CSM user profile has been activated (user change).

E1: InstalledBaseGetRequest is sent to backend and gets return code 304 (no SL received, same SL content in vehicle and backend) or 200 (SL received from Backend, due to different SL in vehicle and backend)
A1: log in an IAA user
The core service master shall send a service list request to the backend, if backend indicates new service list via X-Notify: SL.

E1: InstalledBaseGetRequest is sent to backend and is answered with return code 304 (no SL received, same SL content in vehicle and backend) or 200 (SL received from Backend, due to different SL in vehicle and backend)
A1: set X-Notify-Flag in HTTP Operations
The core service master shall send a service list request to the backend, if backend indicates new servicelist via MQTT-operation: notifySLJob.

E1: InstalledBaseGetRequest is sent to backend and is answered with return code 304 (no SL received, same SL content in vehicle and backend) or 200 (SL received from Backend, due to different SL in vehicle and backend)
The CoreServiceMaster shall store the received ServiceList persistently.
E6: ServiceList data is the same
A1: check filesize and date of creation of ServiceList saved on OCU (mnt/legato/vwi/mods/data/OnlineServiceList.json)
A6: compare current ServiceList data with previous data from A1
The MOD shall stop collecting, using and sending any user related data while disabled via at least one disableReason
E4: service is disabled in logs, service stops running immediately
A1: choose a service which is enabled in vehicle and running and has blocksDisabling=false (e.g. Webradio)
A2: create a SL mock with disableReason "noActiveLicense" for the chosen service from A1
A3: perform a quick CL15 cycle
A4: check logs and check if the chosen service is still running
Upon reception of a http 304 not modified from the backend, the vehicle shall take the previously received service list as the new service list.
E2: OCU gets status code 304 and uses stored ServiceList further
Upon reception of the ServiceList as defined in the GLCS OTA Specification Service Management [], the OCU/cGW shall offer the received information to the MIB via BAP.
E1: InstalledBaseGetRequest gets HTTP return Code 200, SL is received
E2: OCU provides ServiceList's information via BAP by using the changedArray method in BAP_ENI for the ServiceList array
E3: service properties of all grey services are like in the ServiceList received from backend
A3: check service propertiers of some grey service on HMI

Upon reception of the ServiceList as defined in the GLCS OTA Specification Service Management [8], the OCU/cGW shall offer the received information to the clients via RSI: - serviceManagement.services - serviceManagement.licenses - serviceManagement.operations
E1: InstalledBaseGetRequest gets HTTP return Code 200, SL is received
E2: OCU provides ServiceList's informations via RSI ViwiServerService: notifyServiceListChanged
E3: service properties of all grey and all colored services on MIB are like in the ServiceList received on OCU from backend
A3: check service properties of grey and colored services on MIB
The system shall provide the possibility to locally disable services, check whether a service may be disabled (blocksDisabling=false) and send the new vehicle local service state to the backend.
E1: services are shown as disabled in HMI with reason "deactivated by user"
E2: LocalServiceState Request is sent to Backend by lsd_v1, HTTP return code 204
E3: user-specific operation list on Backend contains changed service states
E4: user gets notification in CWP and APP about deactivation of a service, CWP and APP show the grey service as disabled
A1: disallow a specific grey service and a specific colored service via HMI
A3: check user-specific operation list for anonymous guest user on backend via MBB admin tool (user monitoring)
The system shall provide the possibility to locally disable services, check whether a service may be disabled (blocksDisabling=false) and send the new vehicle local service state to the backend.
E1: a grey service and a colored service are disabled
E2: services are shown as enabled in HMI
E3: LocalServiceState Request is sent to Backend by lsd_v1, HTTP return code 204
E4: user-specific operation list on Backend contains changed service states
E5: CWP and APP show the grey service as enabled
A2: allow a disabled grey service and a disabled colored service via HMI
A4: check user-specific operation list for anonymous guest user on backend via MBB admin tool (user monitoring)
The system shall provide the possibility to locally disable services, check whether a service may be disabled (blocksDisabling=false) and send the new vehicle local service state to the backend.
E1: the chosen grey service is shown as disabled in HMI with reason "deactivated by user"
E2: - Serial2: LocalServiceState Request is sent to Backend by lsd_v1, HTTP return code 200
- BAP: SetGet, ChangedArray, StatusArray can be seen for the chosen grey service
E3: user-specific operation list on Backend contains changed service state
E4: user gets notification in CWP and APP about deactivation of a service, CWP and APP show the grey service as disabled
A1: disallow a specific grey service via HMI
A2: check OCU traces (Serial2 and BAP viewer)
A3: check user-specific operation list for anonymous guest user on backend via MBB admin tool (user monitoring)
The system shall provide the possibility to locally disable services, check whether a service may be disabled (blocksDisabling=false) and send the new vehicle local service state to the backend.
E1: a grey service is disabled
E2: service is shown as enabled in HMI
E3: - Serial2: LocalServiceState Request is sent to Backend by lsd_v1, HTTP return code 200
- BAP: SetGet, ChangedArray, StatusArray can be seen for the chosen grey service
E4: user-specific operation list on Backend contains changed service state
E5: CWP and APP show the grey service as enabled
A2: allow a disabled grey service via HMI
A3: check OCU traces (Serial2 and BAP viewer)
A4: check user-specific operation list for anonymous guest user on backend via MBB admin tool (user monitoring)
If a service has set blocks disabling, the HMI shall not provide the possibility to disable the service locally.
E1: service is listed in HMI but it is not possible to deactivate it
A1: deactivate a service with blocksDisabling=true (e.g. ecall_v1) via HMI
If a service has set blocks disabling, OCU shall discard any user attempt to deactivate the service locally.
E1: service is listed in HMI but it is not possible to deactivate it
A1: deactivate a service with blocksDisabling=true (e.g. ecall_v1) via HMI

If there is a mismatch of the local service state between backend and vehicle for any service, the vehicle shall send an updated service state of the missmatching services in a "vehicle local service state list" to the backend. This mechanism needs to be active in case of HTTP304 (Not Modified) as well.
E3: lsd_v1 does retry in under 90s then stops
E7: OperationList does not contain the current local service state that is in vehicle
E8: InstalledBaseGetRequest gets http status code 200
E9: local service state is sent to backend
E10: OperationList does contain the current local service state that is in vehicle
A1: mock an lsd_v1 request answer to send http status code 404
A2: disallow a specific service in HMI
A3: wait for retry to finish (3,3,3,60s)
A5: remove mock for lsd_v1 request
A6: mock an IntsalledBaseGetRequest answer to send http status code 200
A7: check OperationList for specific user in backend
A10: check OperationList for specific user in backend

If there is a mismatch of the local service state between backend and vehicle for any service, the vehicle shall send an updated service state of the missmatching services in a "vehicle local service state list" to the backend. This mechanism needs to be active in case of HTTP304 (Not Modified) as well.
E3: lsd_v1 does retry in under 90s then stops
E7: OperationList does not contain the current local service state that is in vehicle
E8: InstalledBaseGetRequest gets http status code 304
E9: no local service state is sent to backend
E10: OperationList still does not contain the current local service state that is in vehicle
A1: mock a lsd_v1 request answer to send http status code 404
A2: disallow a specific service in HMI
A3: wait for retry to finish (3,3,3,60s)
A5: remove mock for lsd_v1 request
A6: mock an IntsalledBaseGetRequest answer to send http status code 304
A7: check OperationList for specific user in backend
A10: check OperationList for specific user in backend
OCU/cGW shall ignore all other disableReasons than "localVehicleDisabled" within the POST message.

OCU/cGW shall ignore all other disableReasons than "localVehicleDisabled" within the POST message.

The core service master shall check, whether the service has blocksDisabling=true, and shall not change the localService state in the ECU in that case. Appropriate feedback shall be given by an update of the ServiceList array to the MIB
E1: localServiceState in OCU does not change
E2: disableReason (if set) is the same as before

A1: send a message via RSI/BAP to a specific service (uuid) on OCU with a local deactivation of a single service which has blocksDisabling = true (i.e. ecall_v1) -> curl -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -X POST -d '{"disableReasons": ["localVehicleDisabled"]}' http://localhost:9773/servicemanagement/services/<UUID>

The core service master shall check whether the service is disabled by MBB (Disabled by MBB, Main User contract not completed, Main User not verified, No active license available, Disabled by main user via Web Portal) and not change that state in case activation is not allowed. Appropriate feedback shall be given by an update of the ServiceList array.
E1: localServiceState in OCU does not change
E2: disableReason (if set) is the same as before

A1: send a message via RSI/BAP to OCU with an local activation of a single service which is disabled by backend -> curl -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -X POST -d '{"disableReasons": []}' http://localhost:9773/servicemanagement/services/<UUID>
When calling a service, the backend shall provide the information that the service is disabled via an error code over the FAL.

E2: service is not usable and shown as deactivated

When calling a service, the backend shall provide the information that the service is disabled via an error code over the FAL.

OCU informs backend about acknowledge by the user,

OCU informs the backend about the acknowledge by the user using the corresponding request defined in the GLCS specification,
the OCU informs the HMI about a successfull sending using the BAP_ENI.RemoteProcessState

user will be guided into the In-Car shop

OCU tries to inform backend, but it fails,

HMI ignores the warn flags (no popup)

TestCase.Name: CSM_MIB_Service is enabled, licensed - Service can be used

TestCaseEntry.Text: Specific grey and colored service in the service list,
is licensed or does not required a license.
A1: Try to use grey service.
A2: Try to use colored service.

To reach dormantMode each master/independent service shall be assigned to at least one privacy group. The group is dynamically defined within the service list. (valid groups are: personalGps, pseudonymousGps, personalUser and dormantService)
E2: every Master service/Independent service in the ServiceList is assigned to a privacy group (for EU projects).

Multiple Groups can be set for one service at the same time. If all of the groups that are defined for a service are set to “deactivated” then the disableReason privacyConflict is added. If only some (but not all) groups are set to “deactivated”, the disableReason privacyConflict is not added (in this case the service itself is responsible to not send any data that belongs the deactivated group(s)).
E2: service is still running, but it has limited functionality
A1: choose a service from ServiceList, which is allocated to multiple privacy groups (e.g. cc_breakdown)
A2: change privacy mode, so that only one or more of the service's group are deactivated, but not all
A3: change privacy mode, so that all service's groups are deactivated

For a SlaveID the disable reason “privacyConflict” is set: - when all MasterIDs for this particular SlaveID have at least one of the following disable reasons set: privacyConflict localVehicleDisabled - is unset when at least one MasterID for this particular SlaveID does not have at least one of the following disable reasons set: privacyConflict localVehicleDisabled - is independent of all other disable reasons of its MasterIDs

Each service called from app must be executed, no matter if service is locally disabled or not. Since the app and other frontends are being informed about the privacy state, theoretically it shall not be possible that a locally disabled service is being called from frontend side. If it does due to asynchronism between frontend and backend, service shall be executed. It will be rejected by the vehicle and not executed on vehicle side.

E3: service is rejected by vehicle

Brand- and market specific default privacy settings must be adjustable during production of the vehicle in order to fulfill varying legal requirements. Custom privacy settings (adjusted by the customer via HMI) must be made available for readout, after production and after factory reset those custom privacy settings must be adjusted to the default privacy settings. To control the privacy by default settings, that are to be set within the vehicle in case no personalized user has been detected, a switch between two options shall be made available.
E4: default privacy settings are applied by OCU (see OCU logs)
E6: privacy mode is set to Tracking, Tracking icon in HMI is shown
default privacy parameter set#3 set to "Default settings to be applied" via ODIS
A1: change default privacy parameter set#1 via ODIS to "Tracking-Data active"
A2: reboot OCU via ODIS Hex Service 1102
A3: wait until OCU reboot is completed and change privacy mode to INCOGNITO
A4: turn clamp15 and S OFF
A6: check OCU logs and HMI

The vehicle system must go into stop mode until next terminal 15 on event if any of the two energy budgets is exhausted. Upon reaching the approximate end of either of the energy budgets, the vehicle system shall emit the AnnounceEnergyBudgetExpiration event at a sufficient time before exhausting the budget so that the actual sending of the event shall not cause the system to over-exhaust the budget.
E3: CCU switches to STOP mode.
AnnounceStopModeRequest is sent to MBB with stop mode reason "24hBudgetExpired".
AnnounceStopModeRequest is responed with Status code 200.
A1: Set the EnergyBudget24h to 50mAh via diagnosis.
A3: Wait until 24h energy budget expires.
A4: Wait for AnnounceStopModeRequest in CCU log.
The vehicle system should switch between full operation mode and CAN sleep mode according to the relevant vehicle specifications and follow the relevant CAN follow-up times (timer t1).
E2: No more traffic on CAN bus.
E3: CCU log: Switch from operation to can sleep mode.
A3: Verify if CCU has switched to CAN sleep mode.

E3.4: The OCU continues with the Retry&Backoff mechanism.

E4.2: The OCU continues the Retry mechanism and doesn't reset the retry after switching Clamp15 off and on

It shall be tested, if the OCU employs a suitible retry mechanism, if it receives the HTTP 4** (besides 401 and 403) on GET tptruststore request.
E2.1: OCU sends tptruststore request. Backoff level is set to 0, retry timer is started. Truststore Retry Counter is set to 0.
E2.2: OCU receives HTTP 4** (besides 401 and 403) on GET tptruststore request.
E2.3: OCU sends tptruststore request after 3 sec from previous attempt. Truststore Retry Counter is upcounted.
E2.4: OCU repeats step E2.2 to E2.3 until Truststore_Retry Counter is set to 2, such that three attempts at backoff level 0 were made.
E2.5: OCU sets backoff level to 1.
E2.6: OCU sends tptruststore request after 60 sec from previous attempt. Truststore Retry Counter is upcounted.
E2.7: OCU receives HTTP 4** (besides 401 and 403) on GET tptruststore request.
E2.8: OCU repeats step E2.6 to E2.7 until Truststore_Retry Counter is set to 5, such that three attempts at backoff level 1 were made.
E2.9: OCU sets backoff level to 2.
E2.10: OCU sends tptruststore request after 1800 sec + random(600sec) from previous attempt. Truststore Retry Counter is upcounted.
E2.11: OCU receives HTTP 4** (besides 401 and 403) on GET tptruststore request.
E2.12: OCU repeats step E2.10 to E2.11 until Truststore_Retry Counter is set to 8, such that 3 attempts at backoff level 2 were made.
E2.13: OCU sets backoff level to 3.
E2.14: OCU sends tptruststore request after 10800 sec + random(3600sec) from previous attempt. Truststore Retry Counter is upcounted.
E2.15: OCU receives HTTP 4** (besides 401 and 403) on GET tptruststore request.
E2.16: OCU repeats step E2.14 to E2.15 infinitely.
P3: Configure backend to send a HTTP 4** (besides 401 and 403) on GET tptruststore.
P4: Vehicle is known at backend

E2.1: OCU sends tptruststore request. Backoff level is set to 0, retry timer is started. Truststore Retry Counter is set to 0.
E2.2: OCU receives HTTP 401 on GET tptruststore request. Error code is an invalid token.
E2.5: OCU sends tptruststore request after 3 sec from previous attempt. Truststore Retry Counter is upcounted.
E2.6: OCU repeats step E2.2 to E2.5 until Truststore_Retry Counter is set to 2, such that three attempts at backoff level 0 were made.
E2.7: OCU sets backoff level to 1.
E2.8: OCU sends tptruststore request after 60 sec from previous attempt. Truststore Retry Counter is upcounted.
E2.9: OCU receives HTTP 401 on GET tptruststore request. Error code is an invalid token.
E2.12: OCU repeats step E2.8 to E2.11 until Truststore_Retry Counter is set to 5, such that three attempts at backoff level 1 were made.
E2.13: OCU sets backoff level to 2.
E2.14: OCU sends tptruststore request after 1800 sec + random(600sec) from previous attempt. Truststore Retry Counter is upcounted.
E2.15: OCU receives HTTP 401 on GET tptruststore request. Error code is an invalid token.
E2.18: OCU repeats step E2.14 to E2.17 until Truststore_Retry Counter is set to 8, such that 3 attempts at backoff level 2 were made.
E2.19: OCU sets backoff level to 3.
E2.20: OCU sends tptruststore request after 10800 sec + random(3600sec) from previous attempt. Truststore Retry Counter is upcounted.
E2.21: OCU receives HTTP 401 on GET tptruststore request. Error code is an invalid token.
E2.24: OCU repeats step E2.20 to E2.23 infinitely.
P3: Configure backend to send a HTTP 401 on GET tptruststore with error code "invalid token".

It shall be tested, if the OCU employs a suitable retry mechanism on a VKMS Request (challenge, statusfeedback or dlc) in case of a malformed URL.
E2.1: OCU receives MalformedURLException on attempting to send a base certificate request
E2.3: OCU starts retry mechanism on backoff level 0. The OCU sends the base certificate request with a delay of 3 sec. This is repeated unltil three tries are done.
E2.4: OCU switches to retry mechanism on backoff level 1. The OCU sends the base certificate request with a delay of 60 sec. This is repeated unltil three tries are done.
E2.6: OCU switches to retry mechanism on backoff level 2. The OCU sends the base certificate request with a delay of 1800 sec + random(600 sec). This is repeated unltil three tries are done.
E2.7: OCU switches to retry mechanism on backoff level 3. The OCU sends the base certificate request with a delay of 10800 sec + random(3600 sec). This is repeated unlimitedly.
P2: No RegisterAndPairing was performed yet.

E2.1: OCU sends service request. Backoff level is set to 0, retry timer is started. MOD Retry counter is set to 0.
E2.3: OCU sends service request after 3 sec from previous attempt. MOD Retry Counter is upcounted.
E2.4: OCU repeats step E4.2 to E4.3 until MOD Counter is set to 2, such that three attempts at backoff level 0 were made.
E2.5: OCU sets backoff level to 1.
E2.6: OCU sends service request after 60 sec from previous attempt. MOD Retry Counter is upcounted.
E2.8: OCU repeats step E4.6 to E4.7 until MOD Counter is set to 5, such that three attempts at backoff level 1 were made.

E2.12: OCU repeats step E4.10 to E4.11 until MOD Counter is set to 7, such that 2 attempts at backoff level 2 were made.
E2.13: OCU notifies MOD service about unsuccessfull retry mechanism

It shall be tested if the OCU starts the retry mechanism even though it is in StandBy Mode. The OCU detects a data connection loss and tries to re-establish the connection as soon as the data connection is restored. After detection of data connection loss and broker connection loss: for each MQTT connection, Java shall set a Wake Lock by "Acquire wake lock". After MQTT connection has been re-established, Java shall remove the wake lock set by“Release wake lock”, for the last connection only. After trigger "messageArrived", Java shall set a temporary wake lock for each arrived message.
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:teltech: MSG BE MQTT DATA CONNECTION LOST
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:teltech: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Acquire wake lock
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:tel: MSG BE MQTT DATA CONNECTION LOST
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:tel: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Acquire wake lock
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:tel: MSG BE MQTT CONNACK – onSuccess
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:tel: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Release wake lock
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:tel: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Set temporary wake lock
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:tel: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Set successful
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:teltech: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Set temporary wake lock
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:teltech: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Set successful

It shall be tested if the OCU starts the retry mechanism even though it is in Standby Mode, if the TCP connection has been lost, while the data connection remains available ("data:true"). Due to standby mode, the MQTT Ping Pong Timer is active. At some time, OCU Java detects a broker connection loss by the MQTT handler's message "connectionLost". The OCU shall try to re-establish the broker connection. After detection of broker connection loss: for each MQTT connection, Java shall set a Wake Lock by "Acquire wake lock". After MQTT connection has been re-established, Java shall remove the wake lock set by “Release wake lock”, for the last connection only. After trigger "messageArrived", Java shall set a temporary wake lock for each arrived message.
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:teltech: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Acquire wake lock
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:tel: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Acquire wake lock
The DATA_CONNECTION_LOST must not be seen in the logs.
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:tel: MSG BE MQTT CONNACK – onSuccess
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:tel: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Release wake lock
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:tel: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Set temporary wake lock
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:tel: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Set successful
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:teltech: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Set temporary wake lock
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:teltech: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Set successful

- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:tel: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Set successful
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:teltech: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Set temporary wake lock
- MqttHandler/CommandBroker/t1_v:teltech: MSG BE MQTT AP WAKE LOCK - Set successful

The Job mechanism for an OCU that is online shall be tested.
E2.1: The OCU receives a PUBLISH packet from the C-broker to the topic: VIN/<VIN>/rlu_v1/remoteLockJob with a messageID=XX
E2.2: OCU sends Reception Acknowledgement with the result code "SUCCESS" to the topic VIN/<VIN>/rlu_v1/remoteLockJob/result
The messageID of the result payload is the same as the messageID of the wire message (messageId=XX)

The Job mechanism with wakeup for an OCU that is offline shall be tested. The OCU shall wakeup after receiving the wakeup SMS.
E2.1: The OCU receives a Wakeup SMS and switches from Standby mode to Operational mode
E2.2: The OCU receives a PUBLISH packet from the C-broker to the MQTT job topic with a messageId = XX
E2.3: The OCU sends the Reception Acknowledgement with the result code "SUCCESS" to the MQTT job result topic with the same messageId=XX

It shall be tested if a job is successfully sent to OCU after the vehicle is ONLINE again.

E3.2: OCU sends a PUBACK packet
E4.1: Backends forward job from outbound dispatcher to queue
E4.2: Backend sends job to broker once the connection is reestablished
E4.3: Backend receives reception acknowledgment of OCU and notifies job subscription listener

It shall be tested if the OCU purges an MQTT session on receiving an updated SL containing a scope change for some MQTT operations.

E2.6: OCU sends a CONNECT packet with cleanSession=false to establish an MQTT session for the new scope

ER_1: The CAI activation process starts.
ER_2: Alle used certificates are in the X509v3 format with PEM encoding.
ER_3: The certificates use ECC256 with the ECC curve secp256v1/prime256v1 for encryption with SHA256 (SHA1 with OCU-I/MIB2STD SOP1) as a signature algorithm.

ER_4: The OU certificate's CN contains the appropriate fields. Check for VIN=BusVIN. O=VWAG. C=DE and if the same serial number as of the root certificate is used in the selfsigned client certificate.
ER_5: The OU uses its selfsigned certificate when performing register and pairing.
ER_6: The OU verifies the TSP's certificate using the root certificate from VWAG.
ER_7: The following ciphersuite used between OU and TSP (implies use of certificates' keys):
ER_8: The CAI activation process finishes successfully (i.e. the OU has a valid signed certificate).
The OU is reset (Clamp30 off), no CAI activation has taken place, i.e. the OU does not have a signed certificate for regular communication.
The immobiliser/theft protection module of the OU must be properly trained and working.
A_1: Turn on Clamp30 and wait for the CAI activation process to start.
A_2: Check if the used certificates (root certificate and selfsigned client certificate) are in the X509v3 format and stored in PEM form.
A_3: Check the OU's root certificate and selfsigned client certificate: This includes the encryption algorythm of the certificate. the ECC curve and the signature algorithm.
A_4: Check the selfsigned client certificate for the required 'Common Name' (CN) fields.
A_5: Check which certificate is used by the OU when performing register and pairing (verify the certificate in the register and pairing event send to the TSP).
A_6: Check which certificate is used by the OU to verify the TSPs root certificate.
A_7: Check which ciphersuite is used between OU and TSP.
A_8: Wait for the CAI activation process to finish.

ER_1: The CSR of the OCU contains the following appropriate Common Name fields: - CN (Common Name) of the MOD_REG_CERT must be the string "VIN:" + the VIN (17-digit alphanumerical)
- CN (Common Name) of the MOD_REG_CERT must be the string "DA:" + the DA (4-digit hexadecimal)
- O (Owner) of the MOD_REG_CERT must be the string "VWAG"
- C (Country) of the MOD_REG_CERT must be the string "DE"
A_1: Check the Certificate Signing Request (CSR) of the OCU for the required 'Common Name' (CN) fields
Test for the whole CSA process with focus on the security parameters

ER_1: The CLIENT HELLO contains the trusted_ca_keys extension with TrustedAuthorities in the extension_data field. Server responses with known root certificate are contained in the Trusted CA Indication

A_2: Start a regular communication and check for the Trusted CA Indication again

ER_1: The CLIENT HELLO contains in the status_request extension the extension_data field with CertificateStatusRequest ER_2: The CLIENT HELLO contains in the status_request_v2 extension the extension_data field with CertificateStatusRequestListV2 ER_3: The TSP responds with a positive CertificateStatus message (certificate "good") ER_4: The CLIENT HELLO contains in the status_request extension the extension_data field with CertificateStatusRequest ER_5: The CLIENT HELLO contains in the status_request_v2 extension the extension_data field with CertificateStatusRequestListV2 ER_6: The TSP responds with a positive CertificateStatus message (certificate "good")

A_1: Start register and pairing and check the CLIENT HELLO of the TLS connection for Certificate Status Request A_2: Check the CLIENT HELLO of the TLS connection for Multiple Certificate Status Request A_3: Check if the TSP responds with a positive CertificateStatus message A_4: Wait for the activation process to finish and perform any service that requires a connection to the backend. Check for Certificate Status Request again A_5: Check for Multiple Certificate Status Request again. A_6: Check if the TSP responds with a positive CertificateStatus message (certificate "good")

Check if the OCU performs R&P according to the Retry-and-Backoff mechanism after long standby if the R&P events were declined
ER_1 : The CCU does a restart.
ER_2 : The CCU starts R&P including retries due to Retry-and-Back off.
ER_3 : The CCU goes into Standby mode.
ER_4 : The R&P request will be accepted by the backend.
ER_5 : The R&P request is performed by the CCU. The backend has received all R&P request according to Retry-and-Backoff.
P_1 : Configure VIN that the R&P request is rejected by the backend.
A_1 : Perform Clamp30 reset for the CCU.
A_2 : Wait for the CCU to try the R&P.
A_3 : Turn Off the Clamp15 wait for the CCU to be in Standby mode. The CCU has to be in standby for several hours or even days. Best is to execute this test case over the weekend.
A_4 : Configure the VIN so the its R&P request is allowed by the backend.
A_5 : Turn On the Clamp15 wait for the CCU to make the R&P. Check all previous made R&Ps by the CCU.

ER_3: The OU stick at the 'Aktivierungsschwelle'.
ER_4: The OU starts register and pairing.

TestCase.Name: Check if the OU makes use of TLS SNI

ER_2: The ClientHello contains in the server_name the correct name of the server.
The OU is reset (Clamp30 off), no CAI registration has taken place, i.e. the MIB does not have a signed certificate for regular communication.

A_2: Wait for the activation process to finish and perform any service that requires a connection to the backend. Check for TLS SNI again.

TestCase.Name: Root certificate check - root certificate expiration date passed

TestCaseEntry.Text: ER_1: No CAI activation should be starded due to invalid time.
ER_2: The OU cannot establish a connection because the root certificate is invalid.
ER_1: The OU receives a 3D fix and a valid time via GPS.
ER_2: The CAI activation is finished and the connection is closed.
ER_2: The OU discards the client certificate and private key due to an expiration date. Afterwards the attempt to connect to the backend will fail due to a invalid root certificate.
The OU is in either registered or non-registered state.
The OU is reset (Clamp30 off), no CAI registration has taken place, i.e. the OU does not have a signed certificate for regular communication.
A_1: Unplug GPS and power up the OU.
A_2: Create a root certificate with an expiration date in the past and overwrite the root certificate on the OU. Plug GPS and wait for the OU to attempt to connect to the backend.
A_1: Make sure GPS is plugged and OU receives a GPS time.
A_2: Wait for the OU to finish th CAI activation process and that the connection is closed.
A_3: Unplug GPS and change the time on the OU. Wait for the OU to attempt to connect to the backend.
Test of offline DLC usage with invalid SG Basis certificate
ER_1: An error occured on the OCU side during the register and pairing process. The OCU is rejected at the TLS handshake
A_1: Train the OCU with an invalid SG Basis certificate (certificate doesn't match to backend root and leads to a wrong MOSE signature) and restart register and pairing
Test of CSA request with an invalid VIN in the CSR

ER_1: The excluded VIN is loaded in the VKMS module and set as the CAN VIN and no error occured during the toggle of Clamp15 and during the DLC download ER_2: Register and pairing started ER_3: Comparison between VKMS VIN and CAN VIN is successful ER_4: The TSP rejects the activation request due to an invalid VIN in the client certificate (CSR). A new register and pairing starts
The TSP must exclude the VIN for a temporary time, if the VIN has conspicuous behaviour

A_1: Put an excluded blacklist VIN in the VKMS module and set this VIN also as the CAN VIN. A_2: Start register and pairing A_3: Check if the VIN comparison between VKMS VIN and CAN VIN is successful A_4: Check if the TSP rejects the activation request
Test of online DLC trigger with correct parameter
ER_1: The installed base VKMS capability includes the attribute AsymetricKeysOnly
ER_2: The counter for the DLC training is incremented after the train process
A_1: Check if only asymetric keys are used in the VkmsDlcUpdate job
A_2: Check if the DLC training counter is incremented
Test of online DLC trigger with a backend job
ER_1: The OCU receives the Job and triggers the OnlineDlcUpdate
ER_2: The Online DlcUpdate is successfully performed in following Order:
ER_3: The OCU started a new register and pairing
It must be possible to send a VkmsDlcUpdateJob to the OCU
A_1: Send the VkmsDlcUpdatejob to the OCU, so that an OnlineDlcUpdate can be triggered
A_2: Check that the UpdateProcess performs successfully
A_3 : Check if the OCU starts a new register and pairing
Test of online DLC trigger with nearly expired certificates
ER_1: The OCU is trained with an expiring SG Basis certificate
ER_2: The OCU detected the validity of the certificate and triggers an Online DLC Update
A_1: Expire the SG Basis certificate (validity under 1 year) in the VKMS device, so that an Online DLC Update can be triggered
A_2: Trigger clamp15 to start an Online DLC Update
Test of online DLC trigger with expired certificates
ER_1: The OCU is updated with the new certificate
ER_2: The OCU detected the vaildity of the certificate and triggers an online DLC
ER_3: The OCU started a new register and pairing
A_1: Create a SG Basis certificate, which is valid in the future, and overwrite the certificate on the VKMS module using the offline DLC
A_2: Trigger clamp15 (if OCU didn't detect the expiry during communication)
A_3 : Check if the OCU started a new register and pairing
Test of online DLC trigger with correct parameter
ER_1: The Installed Base VKMS capability includes the attribute AsymmetricKeysOnly
ER_2: The counter for the DLC training is incremented after the train process

A_2: Check if the DLC training counter is incremented

ER_2: The Online DlcUpdate is successfully performed in following Order:

A_2: Check that the UpdateProcess performs successfully

ER_2: The TRxM detected the validity of the certificate and triggers an Online DLC Update

ER_2: The VKMS module of the ECU reacts with a error message
DLC mock with incorrect DLC response: too big array size or wrong (old, null) DLC response

A_2: Check the reaction of the ECU to the DLC response
Test regular communication with incorrect VIN
ER_2: A new register and pairing starts, but it will not succeed, because the VKMS and the CAN VIN are different
A_1: Change the CAN VIN to be different as the VKMS VIN
A_2: Toggle Clamp15 and check if a new register and pairing starts, caused by the difference between the CAN VIN ,VKMS VIN and the VIN in the signed certificate
Test regular communication with incorrect VIN
ER_2: A new register and pairing starts, but it will not succeed, because the VKMS and the CAN VIN are different
A_1: Train the OCU with a DLC using a different VKMS VIN than the CAN VIN
A_2: Toggle Clamp15 and check if a new register and pairing starts, caused by the difference between the VKMS VIN, CAN VIN and the VIN in the signed certificate
Test the CSA certificate in case the certificate is deleted
ER_1: The OCU checks if there is a valid backend signed client certificate with the following information:
A_1: Toggle Clamp15 and check if the OCU checks the client certificate
Test the CAI certificate in case the certificate is from another backend
ER_2: Connection to the backend is denied due to a verification error of the CAI certificate on the backend side (probably a TLS handshake error should occur)
A_1: Exchange the current CAI certificate with a CAI certificate that was signed by another root (take the client certificate from a register and pairing with another backend)
A_2: Trigger a connection with the backend and check if the connection possible
Test the CSA certificate in case certificate has a different VIN
ER_1: The old certificate was exchanged with the different one ER_2: A connection to the backend is not possible. A TLS error message appears
A_1: Exchange the new CSA certificate with an certificate that has a different VIN
A_2: Trigger a connection to the AzS and check if communication is possible
Test for correct usage of VKMS root and truststore
ER_1: A third party root certificate from the truststore is used ER_2: An AT is used for the service request and the service started succesfully ER_3: TLS connection is closed successfully

A_3: End the service and heck if the TLS connection ist closed
Test for correct usage of root certificate and truststore

ER_1: The root certificate is used ER_2: An AT is used for the service request and the service started succesfully ER_3: The TLS connection is closed successfully ER_4: The certificate was changed. A connection to the internal backend is not possible. The TLS handshake fails

A_1: Start a service on an internal backend and check which root certificate is used to validate the server certificate A_2: Check if an AT is used to request the service and if the service started succesfully A_3: Close the service and check if the TLS connection is closed successfully A_4: Change the root certificate and start a service with the internal backend
Test for correct usage of root certificate and truststore

ER_1: A third party root certificate from the trust store is used ER_2: An AT is used for the service request and the service started succesfully ER_3: TLS connection is closed successfully ER_4: Truststore changed and communication to external backend is not possible. The TLS handshake fails

A_1: Start a service on an external backend and check which root certificate is used to validate the server certificate A_2: Check if an AT is used to request the service and if the service started succesfully A_3: Close the service and check if the TLS connection is closed successfully A_4: Change the truststore (with invalid certificates) and start a service with an external backend
Test for TLS connection during regular communication
ER_1: Verify that the OCU uses the TLS protocol v1.2 to establish a connection to the TSP. The TLS handshake includes in chronological order:
- SERVER HELLO (from the TSP) alongside certificate. The OCU verifies the TSP certificate using the root certificate
- The OCU sends its self-signed client certificate to the TSP
- Diffie-Hellmann key exchange is performed and the further communication is encrypted
ER_2: The hostname of the CN field and the Subject Alternative Name must be equal. Both hostnames must match the DNS name that the OCU is connecting to
ER_3: Regular communication is possible and the OCU receives a positive HTTP code (200/204)
A_1: Perform any service on the OCU that requires a connection to the backend and validate the TLS connection to the AzS
A_2: Check if the OCU validates the hostname of the Common Name field and the Subject Alternative Name
A_3: Check if the job was processed and if regular communication with the resource server is possible
ER_1: The browser must use the same certificate than the native services.
The OU is reset (Clamp30 off), no CAI registration has taken place, i.e. the MIB does not have a signed certificate for regular communication.
A_1: Perform any browser service and check if the correct root certificate, client certificate and server certificate is used.

TestCase.Name: TSP's certificate check - Passed verification of TSPs certificate and job fetching with regular communication.

TestCaseEntry.Text: ER_1: Verify that the OU uses the following TLS protocol to establish a connection to the TSP:
The TLS handshake includes in chronological order:
- Hello from TSP alongside certificate. The OU verifies this TSP's certificate using the root certificate.
- OU sends signed client certificate to the TSP
- Diffie-Hellmann key exchange is performed and the further communication is encrypted.
ER_2: The hostname of the CN filed and the SubjectAlternativeName must be equal. Both hostnames must match the DNS name the OU is connecting to.
ER_3: The OU uses its signed client certificate when trying to communicate with the TSP.
ER_4: Regular communication is possible and the OU receives a positive HTTP code (HTTP200/HTTP204).
The OU has successfully performed CAI activation and is ready for regular communication.
A_1: Perform any service on the OU which requires a connection to the backend and validate the TLS connection.
A_2: Check if the OU validates the hostname of the CN filed and the SubjectAlternativeName.
A_3: Check which certificate is used by the MIB to fetch the job.
A_4: Check if the job was processed and regular communication is possible.

TestCase.Name: TSP's certificate check - Failed verification of TSP's certificate

TestCaseEntry.Text: ER_1: The OU discards its own signed certificate and generates a new one.
ER_2: The OU tries to perform CAI registration but fails at the connection to the TSP due to a invalid root certificate.
ER_3: The OU tries to register several more times but eventually gives up according to limits put in place.
ER_4: Verify that a connection is possible again (for details see positive testcase).
The OU has successfully performed CAI activation and is ready for regular communication.
A_1: Exchange the root certificate present on the OU against a different valid root certificate. Perform a Clamp15 and wait for the OU to attempt CAI registration (which should fail).
A_2: Check if the OU fails to validate the TSP's certificate
A_3: Repeat the registration process several more times
A_4: Copy the correct certificate back on the OU and perform any service on the OU which requires a connection to the backend.

TestCase.Name: Client certificate check - only latest OU certificate valid

TestCaseEntry.Text: ER_1: The OU discards the certificate and private key and a new CAI activation started. After the activation response the TLS connection must be aborted and a new TLS connection with the signed certificate must be established.
ER_2: The new CAI registration finishes successfully (i.e. the OU has a valid signed certificate).
ER_3: After power up no CAI activation should be performed
ER_4: The OU discards the copied over certificate and private key due to a incorrect OCRN_B and performs a new CAI registration
The OU has successfully performed CAI activation and is ready for regular communication.
A_1: Copy the OU certificate and private key for later use. Perform a Clamp30 reset and wait for an activation response
A_2: Wait for the CAI activation to finish.

A_3: Do a ClampS off and wait for power down of the device. e.g. 1 minute (MIB2STD) or EnergyBudget (OCU-I, OCU-II, cGW). Afterwards power on the device with Clamp15 on. Make sure that the OU was completely shut down, i.e. MIB2STD shows the splash screen.
A_4: Copy the previously saved certificate and private key over the new ones.
Wait for the OU to try and establish a connection to the backend.

Note: It is critical important that the Challenge_B is persistently stored in non-volatile memory. Therefore make sure that the OU is completely powered off and no register and pairing will take place after startup.

TestCase.Name: Certificate check - TSP has to check signature of OU's certificate

TestCaseEntry.Text: ER_1: The URL is changed to a different backend.
ER_2: The client certificate and server certificate were successful validated by the old root certificate.
ER_3: The backend rejects the OU connection attempt because of an invalid signature of the client certificate.
The OU has successfully performed CAI activation and is ready for regular communication
A_1: Change the URL of the OU to a different backend.
A_2: Establish a connection to the backend. Exchange the root certificate just after client certificate and server certificate validation.
A_3: Check the validation status of the client certificate by the backend.
Please note: It is time-critical to exchange the root certificate at the correct time. Use a HTTP library, e.g. cURL to perform this testcase.

TestCase.Name: Client certificate check - OU checks own VIN against VIN in OU certificate

TestCaseEntry.Text: ER_1: The MIB discards its own signed certificate. The subsequent registration attempt may fail due to mismatches between the bus VIN and immobiliser/theft protection VIN.
ER_2: The OU starts register and pairing and receives a signed certificate.
The OU has successfully performed CAI activation and is ready for regular communication.
A_1: Change the OU VIN (either through configuration or the CAN-bus (prefered))
A_2: After some time change the VIN back to the immobiliser/theft protection VIN.

TestCase.Name:
Check for a new register and pairing if the vehicle is deleted at the backend.
Only with MBB with admin portal!

TestCaseEntry.Text: ER_1: The required values are stored and viewable for later use.
ER_2: The OU deletes its certificate and private key and performs a new register and pairing request.
ER_3: The selfsigned certificate, challenge, OCRN_A, OCRN_B and ECFP differ from the previous register and pairing request.
The OU is reset (Clamp30 off), no CAI registration has taken place, i.e. the MIB does not have a signed certificate for regular communication.
A_1: Perform register and pairing and store the unsigned certificate, selfsigned certificate, challenge, OCRN, ECFP and signed certificate for later use.
A_2: Delete the vehicle in the backend (delete installedBase/serviceList) and establish a connection to the backend.
A_3: Check the used certificate, challenge, OCRN_A, OCRN_B and ECFP of the new register and pairing request.
ER_1: A new certificate with the same VIN, but different DA is created.
ER_2: The old certificate is overwritten with the new certificate.
ER_3: The certificate is discarded, because the DA does not match the expected value.
The OU has successfully performed CAI activation and is ready for regular communication. The OU is configured for CAI phase 2/SKIPTEST.
A_1: Create a new certificate with CAI phase 2/SKIPTEST that uses a different DA.
A_2: Copy the certificate with the different DA on the OU and overwrite the existing certificate.
A_3: Perform any service which requires a connection to the backend.

TestCase.Name: Check the used Cipher-Suites with OU and TSP.

TestCaseEntry.Text: ER_1: Only one cipher-suite is set by the OU:
ER_2: Only one cipher-suite is set by the TSP (see ER_1).
The OU is reset (Clamp30 off), no CAI registration has taken place, i.e. the MIB does not have a signed certificate for regular communication.
A_1: Check if the OU only set one cipher-suite.
A_2: Check if the TSP only set one cipher-suite, e.g. with SSL scanner.

TestCase.Name:
Check online services without ignition key
This test case is only useful with an OCU1, OCU2/cGW that is active trained to the immobilizer. This testcase can be skiped with a normal trained OCU1, OCU2/cGW.

TestCaseEntry.Text: ER_2: The OU established an online connection successful without ignition key.
The OU has successfully performed CAI activation and is ready for regular communication.
The ignition key is not present in the ignition lock and has not been present in the last minutes.
A_1: Send WakeUpSMS to the OU
A_2: Check if the OU establishes an online connection.
ER_2: The backend should send the UpdateTruststoreJob to the OU.
ER_3: The job list is acknowledged with the old certificate.

ER_4: Register and pairing is performed with the new selfsigned certificate. This certificates contains the serial number of the new root certificate. The new root certificate is used to validate the server certificate. The connection is closed and reestablished after the new certificate is received.
ER_5: The connection is established with the new client certificate using the new root certificate to validate the server sertificate.
The OU has successfully performed CAI activation and is ready for regular communication.
A_2: Establish a connection to the backend.
A_3: Check if the job list is acknowledged.
A_4: Check if register and pairing is performed.
A_5: Wait until the connection is closed and perform any service.

TestCase.Name: OTA Root CA Update after successful update

TestCaseEntry.Text: The OU has successfully performed CAI activation and is ready for regular communication.
ER_2: The backend should send the UpdateTruststoreJob to the OU.
ER_3: The job list is acknowledged with the old certificate.
ER_4: Register and pairing is performed, but fails with a HTTP4xx/HTP5xx.
ER_5: After a few retries there is a rollback to the old client certificate with the old root certificate.
ER_5: The connection is established to the old URL with the old client certificate using the old root certificate to validate the server sertificate.
The OU has successfully performed CAI activation and is ready for regular communication.
A_2: Establish a connection to the backend.
A_3: Check if the job list is acknowledged.
A_4: Check if register and pairing is performed.
A_5: Check if after a few retries a rollback takes place.
A_6: Wait until the connection is closed and perform any service.

Select an unpersonalized service for this testcase

A_2: Start an unpersonalized service for which a vehicle token is needed A_3: Check if the OCU requests (using the client certificate) and receives an AT from the AzS A_4: Check if the access token is used in the request header and the service has started successfully
Test regular communication with revoked tokens
ER_1: Login is successful ER_2: User deleted. IAA notification is received by the OCU ER_3: The refresh token for the user has been revoked
A RT is already present for the used user in this testcase

Test usage of AuthLevel check for tokenconcept
ER_1: The OCU receives a servicelist from the backend
ER_2: AuthLevel for the service A is set to T1x
ER_3: Service started and the OCU requests a token from AzS
ER_4: Token is saved in the OCU and is used to obtain the service A again
Select a service A for this test
A_1: Wait for the OCU to send the InstalledBasePutRequest to the backend
A_2: Check if the AuthLevel for the service A in the servicelist is set to T1x
A_3: Start a service and check if the OCU directly requests a token from AzS

A_4: Restart service A and confirm, by checking that the same token is used to request the service, that the token is saved on the OCU and is used a second time to request the same service. This also implies that the OCU does not request a new token from the AzS for service A
Test the whole Tokenconcept with OAuth2.0
ER_1: Tokens were requested using the IdP. The OCU has received an AT and a RT from AzS
ER_2: The TLS connection was mutual (client certificate sent to the AzS)

ER_3: The OCU requests the service from the resource server using only the AT from the AzS ER_4: The OCU requests AzS for a new AT using the RT and the client certificate, because the current AT is invalid
A_1: Start a personalized service and check if the OCU requests an AT and a RT from the AzS using the IdT with intended scope

A_2: Check also that this TLS connection is mutual (client certificate was also sent to the AzS) A_3: Check if the OCU requests the service from the resource server using only the AT from the AzS (not mutual TLS!) A_4: Close and restart the service after waiting for validity time of the AT and check if the OCU requests a new AT from the AzS using the RT and client certificate with intended scope (and authorization header- >1108)
Test the Tokenconcept without OpenID1.0 (for RTM only) This test is only for vehicle tokens
ER_1: Tokens are requested and the OCU has received an AT (and a RT) from AzS (with mutual TLS)
ER_2: The OCU requests the service from the resource server using AT in the request header with the keyword "Authorization: Bearer <AT>"
ER_3: A client certificate is not used in the TLS handshake ER_4: The OCU requests AzS for a new AT using the RT and the client certificate, because the current AT is invalid

A_3: Check if a Client certificate is used in the TLS Handshake with the resource server
A_4: Close and restart the service after waiting for validity time of the AT and check if the OCU requests a new AT from the AzS using the client certificate

TestCase.Name: Check limited functionality flag and OCRN generation

TestCaseEntry.Text: ER_1: The OU can not generate a certificate because it is in limited functionality mode. R&P does not commence.
ER_2: The OU generates a certificate and performs register and pairing.
The OU is reset (Clamp30 off), no CAI registration has taken place, i.e. the MIB does not have a signed certificate for regular communication.
A_1: Unplug the immobilizer master (instrument cluster) for OCU-I/OCU-II/cGW or theft protection master (gateway) for MIB2STD. Do a Clamp30 or delete the certificate to do register and pairing.
A_2: Plug the immobilizer master/theft protection master and establish a connection to the backend.

TestCase.Name: Check if the OU waits for data set download.

TestCaseEntry.Text: ER_1: The OU should pass the time check and 'Aktivierungsschwelle', but must not start register and pairing.
ER_2: The OU finishes register and pairing successful.
The OU is a fresh device which has never be trained to a car or test bench.
A_2: Train the OU to the immobilizer/theft protection system.
Test the CRL URL and CRL format
ER_1: OCU receives a CRL from the backend
ER_2: CRL is in X.509 format
ER_3: The signature algorithm is ECDSA SHA256
ER_4: The issuer is the VW Root CA
ER_5: The CRL is valid (must be a date in the past)
ER_6: There is an update time available (must be a date in the future)
ER_7: OCU verifies the CRL signature
ER_8: The OCU uses CRL for a TLS handshake
A_1: Start register and pairing and check if a CRL is received from the CRL URL in the Server Certificate
A_2: Check if the CRL is in the X.509 format
A_3: Check the used signature algorithm of the CRL
A_4: Check the issuer of the CRL
A_5: Check if the CRL is valid (validity time)
A_6: Check the next update time of the CRL
A_7: Check if the OCU verifies the CRL signature
A_8: Check if CRL is in usage for the TLS handshake with the AzS and Ressource Server
ER_1: A local cache of the CRL is used to verify the current certificate
ER_2: The OCU checks the CRL for its validity date
A_1: Start a service (TLS connection with backend) and check if a cached CRL is used
A_2: Verify that the OCU checks the CRL for its validity date
ER_1: Server certificate revoked in the CRL
ER_2: Communication fails due to revoked certificates
A_1: Revoke the server certificate used in the TLS connection from server side (modify the CRL)
A_2: Trigger communication or trigger CRL check with the backend and check if revocation works
ER_1: L2 certificate revoked in the CRL
ER_2: Communication fails due to revoked certificates
A_1: Revoke the L2 certificate using the CRL (modify the CRL)
A_2: Trigger communication or trigger CRL check with the backend and check if revocation works
ER_1: SG Basis certificate revoked in the CRL
ER_2: Communication fails due to revoked certificates
A_1: Revoke the SG Basis certificate using the CRL (modify the CRL)
A_2: Trigger communication or trigger CRL check with the backend and check if revocation works
ER_1: OCU3 updated with a oversized CRL.
ER_2: Further communication failed with error: "CRL check not ok".
A_1: Update the OCU3 with a oversized CRL (Trigger communication)
A_2: Check if further communication is possible.
ER_1: OCU updated with an invalid CRL
A_1: Update the OCU with a CRL, which has an Updatetime in the past (trigger communication)
A_2: Check if further communication is possible
ER_1: CRL distribution point configured to an incorrect URL
ER_2: CRL download failed because the URL is incorrect
A_1: Set an incorrect distribution point for CRL download
A_2: Update the OCU with the latest CRL (trigger communication)
ER_1: CRL distribution point configurated to an URL where no CRL exists
ER_2: CRL not found at the current URL

A_2: Update the OCU with the latest CRL (trigger communication)
